results.title: Vector kinematics
results.creator_credit: Jack Churchill, Kevin Smith and Educational Services Incorporated
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”
Displacement, velocity and acceleration vectors are demonstrated for circular, simple harmonic and other two-dimensional motions, displayed visually on a cathode ray tube screen by an electronic computer. Francis L. Friedman discusses their relationships.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Churchill, Kevin Smith and Educational Services Incorporated

results.title: Universal gravitation
results.creator_credit: Jack Churchill, Kevin Smith and Educational Services, Inc.
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”
Defines the law of universal gravitation by visualising a solar system of one star and one planet. Demonstrates the kinematics and dynamics of planetary motion. Uses a digital computer to display satellite orbits.
Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Churchill, Kevin Smith and Educational Services, Inc.

results.title: Speed of light
results.creator_credit: Stephen White, Kevin Smith and Educational Services, Inc.
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Shows the measuring of the speed of light in air at night, using a spark-gap, a photocell, parabolic mirrors and an oscilloscope. Also studies the speed of light in air and water in a laboratory, using a high-speed rotation mirror.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stephen White, Kevin Smith and Educational Services, Inc.
results.description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Shows the measuring of the speed of light in air at night, using a spark-gap, a photocell, parabolic mirrors and an oscilloscope. Also studies the speed of light in air and water in a laboratory, using a high-speed rotation mirror.
description_for_label:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Shows the measuring of the speed of light in air at night, using a spark-gap, a photocell, parabolic mirrors and an oscilloscope. Also studies the speed of light in air and water in a laboratory, using a high-speed rotation mirror.

results.title: Sound waves in air
results.creator_credit: Quentin Brown, Kevin Smith and Educational Services, Inc.
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Investigates wave characteristics of sound transmission with large-scale equipment, using frequencies up to 5000 cycles. Experiments in reflection, diffraction, interference and refraction are supplemented by ripple-tank analogies. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Quentin Brown, Kevin Smith and Educational Services, Inc.
results.description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.

results.title: The Rutherford atom
results.creator_credit: Quentin Brown, Kevin Smith, Physical Sciences Study Committee and Educational Services Incorporated
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
A cloud chamber and gold foil in a simple alpha-particle scattering experiment illustrates the historic Rutherford experiment which led to the nuclear model of the atom. Behaviour of alpha particles clarified by use of large scale models illustrating the nuclear atom and Coulomb scattering.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Quentin Brown, Kevin Smith, Physical Sciences Study Committee and Educational Services Incorporated
results.description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
A cloud chamber and gold foil in a simple alpha-particle scattering experiment illustrates the historic Rutherford experiment which led to the nuclear model of the atom. Behaviour of alpha particles clarified by use of large scale models illustrating the nuclear atom and Coulomb scattering.

results.title: The Millikan experiment
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Simplified experiment substituting standard spheres for oil drops; analysis of the charge related to the velocity of the sphere across field of view of microscope emphasises the evidence that charge comes in natural units that are all alike; numerous changes of charge are shown, produced by X-rays.
results.description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Simplified experiment substituting standard spheres for oil drops; analysis of the charge related to the velocity of the sphere across field of view of microscope emphasises the evidence that charge comes in natural units that are all alike; numerous changes of charge are shown, produced by X-rays.
description_for_label:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.

results.title: Introduction to optics
results.creator_credit: Norton Bloom and Educational Services Incorporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Elbert P. Little discusses the approximation that light travels in a straight line and demonstrates how its direction is changed by diffraction, scattering, refraction and reflection. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.

results.title: The Interference of photons
results.creator_credit: Physical Sciences Study Committee and Educational Services Incorporated
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Presents an experiment at MIT in which light exhibits both particle and wave characteristics. Characteristic interference pattern is pointed out by many individual photons hitting at places consistent with the interference pattern.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Physical Sciences Study Committee and Educational Services Incorporated
results.description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Presents an experiment at MIT in which light exhibits both particle and wave characteristics. Characteristic interference pattern is pointed out by many individual photons hitting at places consistent with the interference pattern.

results.title: Inertial mass
results.creator_credit: Norton Bloom, Stephen White and Educational Services Incorporated
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Edward M. Purcell demonstrates that acceleration is inversely proportional to mass with force constant and that different objects may have the same inertial mass. Compares inertial and gravitational mass and shows how they are proportional. A continuation of the film “Inertia”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Norton Bloom, Stephen White and Educational Services Incorporated
results.description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Edward M. Purcell demonstrates that acceleration is inversely proportional to mass with force constant and that different objects may have the same inertial mass. Compares inertial and gravitational mass and shows how they are proportional. A continuation of the film “Inertia”.
description_for_label:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Edward M. Purcell demonstrates that acceleration is inversely proportional to mass with force constant and that different objects may have the same inertial mass. Compares inertial and gravitational mass and shows how they are proportional. A continuation of the film “Inertia”.

results.title: Inertia
results.creator_credit: Physical Sciences Study Committee and Educational Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PSSC physics”.
Edward M. Purcell demonstrates Galileo’s principle of inertia in experiments with a body moving horizontally with minimal friction and using low friction dry-ice pucks and multiple flash photography showing acceleration is proportional to force when mass is constant. Suitable for upper secondary level.
